summary: A 2006 Palm Beach Post article reporting on the defense strategy of Jeffrey Epstein's legal team, who publicly attacked the credibility of his teenage accusers and criticized the Palm Beach Police Department's investigation. Epstein's attorneys claimed no illegal activity occurred and that the grand jury's decision to indict only on solicitation of prostitution validated their position.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Palm Beach financier indicted by a grand jury on a charge of felony solicitation of prostitution; accused of sexual misconduct with teenage girls at his waterfront home.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.role: Lead defense attorney for Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Epstein's lead attorney who spoke to the press from Idaho, denying any sex with underage women, attacking the credibility of accusers, and criticizing the Palm Beach Police Department.

persons.name: Michael Reiter
persons.context: Police chief who oversaw the investigation into Epstein, concluded there was evidence for charges of sexual activity with minors, and referred the case to the FBI after the grand jury's lesser indictment.

persons.name: Barry Krischer
persons.context: State Attorney who presented the case to the grand jury; criticized by Epstein's camp for not filing charges directly, though police records show Reiter had earlier suggested Krischer consider disqualification.

persons.name: Dan Klores
persons.context: Publicist who stated Epstein's camp was ready to get their story out to the media.

persons.name: Roy Black
persons.context: Criminal defense attorney who also represented Epstein in the case; a Los Angeles publicist worked for him.

connections.description: Goldberger is Epstein's lead defense attorney, speaking publicly to deny allegations and attack accusers on his behalf.
Black is identified as a criminal defense attorney who also represented Epstein in the case.
Goldberger publicly criticizes Reiter and the Palm Beach Police Department, calling their actions 'childish' and accusing them of using the press to embarrass Epstein.
Reiter wrote to Krischer suggesting he consider disqualification from the prosecution, indicating tension or disagreement over how the case was being handled.
Klores is a publicist working for Epstein's camp to manage media narrative.

events.title: Grand Jury Indictment of Epstein
events.description: A county grand jury indicted Jeffrey Epstein on a charge of felony solicitation of prostitution, a less serious charge than the sexual activity with minors that police recommended.

events.title: Reiter's Letter to Krischer
events.description: Police Chief Michael Reiter wrote to State Attorney Barry Krischer suggesting he consider disqualification from prosecuting the Epstein case.

events.title: Epstein's Defense Goes Public
events.description: Epstein's attorneys and publicists held a press offensive, calling his accusers liars and criticizing the police investigation.

events.title: Palm Beach Police Investigation
events.description: An 11-month investigation by Palm Beach police included sifting through Epstein's trash and surveilling his home, concluding there was evidence to charge him with sexual activity with minors.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein's lead attorney, Jack Goldberger, publicly stated 'There never was any sex between Jeffrey Epstein and any underage women,' claiming accusers were liars with histories of drug abuse and theft.
Epstein was indicted by a grand jury only on felony solicitation of prostitution, despite an 11-month police investigation that found evidence for more serious charges of sexual activity with minors.
Police Chief Michael Reiter referred the case to the FBI for potential federal violations after the grand jury's lesser indictment.
Epstein's defense claimed he paid girls/women $200-$300 for massages but insisted they were over 18, though they had no massage training.
Tension existed between law enforcement and the prosecutor, with Reiter suggesting State Attorney Barry Krischer consider disqualification before the case went to the grand jury.
